questions.text: You are an ENT resident in a hospital. A 60-year-old man comes to you with a history of difficulty in swallowing, which begins soon after he starts eating, halitosis, and a gurgling sound on swallowing. How will you confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario is of Zenker's diverticulum; the confirmatory test is a barium swallow

Pharyngeal pouch (Zenker's Diverticulum): A pulsion diverticulum of the hypopharynx, just above the upper esophageal sphincter.

The inferior constrictor muscle has two parts:

  • Thyropharyngeus with oblique fibres
  • Cricopharyngeus with transverse fibres.

Between these two parts exists a potential gap called Killian's dehiscence.

It is also called "gateway of tears" as perforation can occur at this site during oesophagoscopy.

Etiology: exact cause not known, probably due to spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter or its incoordination during the act of deglutition

Clinical Features:

  • Dysphagia appears after a few swallows when the pouch fills with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • A gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Undigested food may regurgitate at night
  • May have an associated hiatus hernia

Diagnosis: Barium swallow will show the sac and its size.

Treatment options:

  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Dohlman's procedure
  • Endoscopic laser treatment

Explanation of Other Options:

24-hour pH monitoring ( Option A): Used for GERD diagnosis, particularly non-erosive reflux disease (NERD). It measures acid reflux into the esophagus, not structural abnormalities like a pouch.

X-ray lateral view neck (Option C): May show a soft tissue swelling or air-fluid level in large pouches, but it is not reliable for confirmation. Often used in foreign body impaction or retropharyngeal abscess, but not definitive for a pouch.

Manometry (Option D): Measures esophageal motility, used in achalasia or esophageal spasm. May show dysfunction at the upper esophageal sphincter, but is not used to diagnose a pouch directly.

questions.text: A patient with features of sore throat, fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oropharyngeal image is given below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The whitish membrane extending beyond the tonsil and enlarged cervical lymph nodes go in favor of Diphtheria.

Diphtheric tonsillitis

  • Slower in onsetwith less local discomfort
  • Caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • The membrane extends beyond the tonsilto the soft palate, and is dirty grey.
  • It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface.
  • Cervical lymph nodes - particularly the jugulodigastric node become enlarged, Bull neck appearance
  • It can affect the heart(myocarditis) and nerves (soft palate paralysis).

Management:

  • Immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin
  • IV antibiotics: Penicillin or erythromycin
    • Erythromycin
      • Dose: 40-50 mg/kg/day orally or IV, divided every 6 hours
      • Duration: 14 days
    • Penicillin G (Benzylpenicillin)
      • Children:
        • 25,000-50,000 units/kg IV/IM every 6 hours
        • Max: 2-4 million units/day
      • Then follow with oral Penicillin V:
        • 250-500 mg orally every 6 hours to complete 14 days
  • Isolation due to high infectivity

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute Streptococcal Tonsillitis (Option A): Tonsils are enlarged, red, with yellowish or white exudate (not a membrane). Exudate is not adherent and doesn't bleed when removed. Usually, no dirty-gray membrane.

Oral Candidiasis ( Option C): Shows creamy white, curd-like plaques over the oral mucosa and tongue. Easily scraped off, leaving a red base. Not associated with significant fever or toxic appearance. More common in immunocompromised patients, infants, or those on antibiotics/steroids.

Ludwig's Angina (Option D): No pseudomembrane. Presents with Firm swelling in the submandibular area, Elevated tongue, Difficulty in breathing, and Trismus. Oropharynx may appear normal or just displaced by swelling; not the site of primary pathology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive dysphagia, especially for solids. She also reports fatigue and brittle nails. On examination, she has pallor and koilonychia. Blood tests show hypochromic microcytic anemia. Barium swallow reveals a web in the upper esophagus. Which of the following anatomical regions is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis is Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which involves the Postcricoid region

Plummer vinson syndrome(Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome):

Predominantly affects females past 40 years. It is a precancerous condition associated with an increased risk of postcricoid carcinoma

Triad of Plummer-Vinson Syndrome:

  • Dysphagia
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Esophageal web

Barium swallow shows a web in the postcricoid region, and the same can be seen on oesophagoscopy. It is due to subepithelial fibrosis in this region.

Treatment:

  • Iron supplements
  • nutritional support
  • Endoscopic dilation of the web
  • Surveillance

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior pharyngeal wall(Option A): This is a different site, involved in certain pharyngeal infections or malignancies, but not the common location for webs in Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Webs are more distal, in the cervical esophagus.

Valleculae (Option B): It is the depression between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis. A common site for pooling of saliva in oropharyngeal dysphagia, not for webs.

Pyriform sinus(Option D): It is the depression on either side of the laryngeal inlet. A common site for carcinoma of the hypopharynx, but unrelated to webs in this syndrome.

questions.text: The most common malignancy of the oropharynx:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tonsillar malignancy is the most common malignancy of the oropharynx.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common and presents as an ulcerated lesion with a necrotic base.
  • Often linked to HPV infection, especially in younger non-smokers.
  • Lymphomas may present as unilateral tonsillar enlargement with or without ulceration and may simulate an indolent peritonsillar abscess.
  • Clinical presentation: sore throat, dysphagia, otalgia, neck mass (due to early lymph node spread).

Note: Order of frequency in oropharyngeal SCC: Tonsil>Base of tongue>Soft palate>Posterior pharyngeal wall/vallecula

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with structures in the oropharynx except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cleft palate is associated with a hard palate. The hard palate is a part of the oral cavity.

Structures in the oropharynx:

  • Anterior pillar,
  • posterior pillar,
  • palatine tonsil,
  • posterior one-third tongue,
  • lingual tonsil,
  • soft palate,
  • uvula and
  • Vallecula

Explanation of Other Options:

Peritonsillar Abscess (Option A): The Structure involved is the Palatine tonsil. Anatomical location is the Oropharynx.

Lingual Tonsillitis (Option B): The Structure involved is the Lingual tonsil (lymphoid tissue at the base of the tongue). Anatomical location is the Oropharynx.

Foreign Body in Vallecula (Option D): The structure involved is the Vallecula (space between the base of the tongue and the epiglottis). Anatomical location is the Oropharynx.

questions.text: All of these constitute Waldeyer's ring except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Submental lymph nodes are not a part of Waldeyer's ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue, which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer's ring.

Includes:

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil, or the adenoid, or Luschka tonsil
  • Palatine tonsils or faucial tonsil
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils or Gerlach's tonsil
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules(in posterior pharyngeal wall).

Explanation of Options:

Lateral Pharyngeal Bands (Option A): These are extensions of lymphoid tissue running from the palatine tonsils to the pharyngeal tonsil. They form part of the lateral component of the ring and are considered accessory lymphoid tissue.

Lingual Tonsils (Option B): Located at the posterior third of the tongue, these are clusters of lymphoid follicles that form the inferior part of Waldeyer's ring.

Gerlach's Tonsil (Option C): a.k.a. Tubal Tonsil, Situated near the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian (auditory) tube, in the nasopharynx. Part of the lateral wall lymphoid tissue is in the ring.

questions.text: Premalignant lesion of the tongue include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythroplakia is a premalignant lesion of the tongue.

Erythroplakia:

  • Erythroplakia is a red patch or plaque on the oral mucosal surface. A red, velvety patch on the oral mucosa (including tongue) that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be clinically or histologically diagnosed as another condition.
  • Less common than leukoplakia but more dangerous.
  • Occurs mostly in middle-aged to elderly males with risk factors like tobacco, alcohol, and betel nut chewing.
  • Highest malignant transformation rate among oral premalignant lesions (≈ 50-90% show severe dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, or invasive carcinoma at diagnosis).

Management:

  • Biopsy mandatory (since high risk of malignancy).
  • Excision with clear margins if dysplasia is present.
  • Eliminate risk factors (tobacco, alcohol, betel nut).
  • Long-term surveillance.

Note: The premalignant lesions of the oral cavity are leukoplakia, erythroplakia, oral submucous fibrosis, lichen planus, and chronic hyperplastic candidiasis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoriasis(Option B): Autoimmune skin disease, not a premalignant oral lesion.

Aphthous ulcers(Option C): Aphthous ulcers are recurrent and superficial ulcers usually involving the movable mucosa of the oral cavity. Benign, self-limiting ulceration, no malignant potential.

Fordyce Spots(Option D): Aberrant sebaceous glands present under the buccal or labial mucosa and shine through it as yellowish or yellow-brown spots. They are considered normal.

questions.text: On examining a 55-year-old woman, the Murre's sign is positive. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Moure's sign is seen in all the given options except a cancerous base tongue. Absence of laryngeal crepitus is called Moure's sign.

Laryngeal Crepitus :

It is the grating sensation experienced while moving the Thyroid cartilage over the underlying cervical vertebra. It is present in normal people.

It is absent in:

  • Post-cricoid carcinoma
  • Prevertebral abscess
  • Fracture of the thyroid cartilage
  • Retropharyngeal abscess

Absence of laryngeal crepitus is called Moure's sign.

Explanation of Other Options:

Postcricoid carcinoma(Option A): Involves the hypopharynx and is closely related to laryngeal and prevertebral structures. Murre's sign can be positive.

Retropharyngeal abscess(Option B): Lies in a deep neck space that can affect surrounding fascial planes. Murre's sign can be positive.

Fracture of thyroid cartilage(Option C): Directly affects the larynx, swelling may move with swallowing and tongue protrusion, a positive sign.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious. On examination, his tongue is seen to be falling back and obstructing the airway. You recall that paralysis of a particular muscle leads to posterior tongue fall and airway compromise. Which of the following muscles prevents this complication under normal conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In unconscious patients, the tongue may fall backward, potentially obstructing the airway. This is most commonly prevented by the action of the genioglossus muscle.
  • The genioglossus is called the safety muscle of the tongue because the two genioglossus form the bulk of the tongue and are responsible for the protrusion of the tongue.
  • If this muscle is paralysed, the tongue will fall back into the oropharynx and obstruct the air passages.
    • Origin: Superior mental spine (genial tubercle) of mandible
    • Insertion: The Entire length of the tongue and the hyoid bone
    • Action: Protrudes and depresses the tongue

Role in airway:

  • It pulls the tongue forward, preventing it from falling back and blocking the airway.
  • Referred to as the "safety muscle of the tongue" because its tone is crucial in maintaining airway patency, especially during sleep or unconsciousness.

Explanation of Other Options:

Styloglossus (Option A):

  • Origin: Styloid process of the temporal bone
  • Insertion: Side of the tongue
  • Action: Retracts and elevates the tongue
  • Role in airway: Does not prevent the tongue from falling back.

Hyoglossus (Option C):

  • Origin: Body and greater horn of the hyoid bone
  • Insertion: Side of the tongue
  • Action: Depresses the sides of the tongue
  • Role in airway: Does not prevent posterior tongue fall

Palatoglossus (Option D):

  • Origin: Palatine aponeurosis
  • Insertion: Side of the tongue
  • Action: Elevates the back of the tongue and closes the oropharyngeal isthmus
  • Role in airway: Mostly involved in swallowing and speech, not airway maintenance

Parotid is the most common site of origin

Explanation:

Ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst of the sublingual gland. Plunging ranula is a mucous retention cyst of the sublingual & submandibular gland.

It presents as a Bluish Swelling in the Floor of the mouth.

The best treatment is the Removal of Swelling along with Excision of the Sublingual Gland.

For a Larger Ranula, Marsupialization is Done.

Retention cyst of the lower lip mucus glands

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a painless, bluish, translucent swelling in the floor of her mouth, which has been slowly increasing in size over the last two months. She reports mild discomfort during speech and mastication. On palpation, the swelling is soft, fluctuant, and non-tender. There is no history of trauma, fever, or foul-smelling discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario provided, the most probable diagnosis is Ranula.

A ranula is a cystic lesion of the floor of the mouth caused by extravasation of saliva from the sublingual gland, typically following trauma or ductal obstruction.

  • Most commonly seen in the second decade of life, predominantly among Females
  • Genetic predisposition is suspected due to familial clustering and ethnic variation.
  • HIV association: Possibly due to peri-ductal fibrosis from HIV-related salivary gland disease.

Classification:

  • Simple (Intra-oral) Ranula:
    • Above the mylohyoid muscle.
    • Presents as a soft, bluish, painless swelling in the floor of the mouth.
  • Plunging (Cervical) Ranula:
    • Extends through or around defects in the mylohyoid muscle into the submandibular space.
    • Presents as a painless, persistent, or recurrent neck swelling.
    • Rarely extends to the upper chest wall.

Clinical Features:

  • Painless, translucent, bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth.
  • May cause discomfort in speech, mastication, or swallowing.
  • Plunging type presents as a soft, fluctuant swelling in the upper neck.

Imaging Findings:

  • Ultrasound (US): Unilocular, well-defined cystic mass in the submental region. Fine internal echoes from debris (due to prior inflammation).
  • CT Scan: Low attenuation, thin-walled, non-enhancing cyst (simple type). A plunging ranula may show enhancement due to granulation tissue.
  • MRI: Low T1 signal, high T2 signal. Extension into the submandibular space in the plunging type.

Management:

  • Excision of the sublingual gland has, lowest recurrence, but risks include:
    • Lingual nerve injury.
    • Wharton's duct stenosis or injury.
    • Obstructive sialadenitis.
    • Bleeding/hematoma.
  • Marsupialization for small, superficial lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Parotid gland cyst(Option A): A parotid gland cyst is a benign cystic lesion arising within the parotid salivary gland, which is located anterior and inferior to the ear, not the floor of the mouth.

Submandibular gland cyst(Option C): A submandibular gland cyst is a rare benign cystic swelling arising from the submandibular salivary gland or its duct (Wharton's duct). Presents as a swelling in the submandibular triangle, below the mandible.

Retention cyst of lower lip mucus glands(Option D): A benign cystic swelling caused by obstruction of a minor salivary gland duct(Mucocele) in the lower lip, leading to mucus retention inside the duct.
